channel.title: Can't seem to figure out how to send this data to client!
channel.description:
Hey guys,
I found this code in my 550 client... [code=java] int j5 = Class142_Sub27_Sub3.incomingVector.readUnsignedByteA(); int y = Class40.anInt699 + (j5 & 7); int x = KeyHandler.anInt2380 + (7 & j5 >> 4); [/code]
Looks pretty simple enough. I just wanted to know how I should send var j5 to the client. What would the method look like?
What I have tried is... [code=java] j5 = ((x << 4) & 0x7) | (y & 0x7); [/code]
However that just returns 0.
Any suggestions?

You’d send the data like this:

item.source: Can't seem to figure out how to send this data to client!

item.title: Can't seem to figure out how to send this data to client!
item.dc:creator: @my-swagger my-swagger
item.description:
@my-swagger wrote:

[quote=“Roar337, post:2, topic:554722”]Your integer j5 is being assigned a value through a incoming stream.

Class142_Sub27_Sub3.incomingVector.readUnsignedByteA();

The server uses a code like

stream.sendInt(myInt);

And the client reads it in a similar manner

client.getStream.readInt();

Unfortunately I cant tell you much more I advise you do a little research on streams and sockets and how clients and servers talk make yourself a basic test application
and tinker to learn more.[/quote]

That makes no sense. I am already sending the correct data type.

Notice:

int y = Class40.anInt699 + (j5 & 7); int x = KeyHandler.anInt2380 + (7 & j5 >> 4);

The X/Y are generated from the j5 variable. What I was trying to work out was how to generate the value the client needs.
I can now do this already.

Read full topic
item.source: Can't seem to figure out how to send this data to client!

item.title: Can't seem to figure out how to send this data to client!
item.dc:creator: @Roar337 Roar337
item.description:
@Roar337 wrote:

Your integer j5 is being assigned a value through a incoming stream.

Class142_Sub27_Sub3.incomingVector.readUnsignedByteA();

The server uses a code like

stream.sendInt(myInt);

And the client reads it in a similar manner

client.getStream.readInt();

Unfortunately I cant tell you much more I advise you do a little research on streams and sockets and how clients and servers talk make yourself a basic test application
and tinker to learn more.

Read full topic

int x = KeyHandler.anInt2380 + (7 & j5 >> 4);

Looks pretty simple enough. I just wanted to know how I should send var j5 to the client. What would the method look like?

What I have tried is…

j5 = ((x << 4) & 0x7) | (y & 0x7);

However that just returns 0.

Any suggestions?
